newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICA UNVEILS PLANS FOR WATER CHARGES.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICA UNVEILS PLANS FOR WATER CHARGES.

text.p: Water Affairs and Forestry Minister Kader Asmal on Monday unveiled plans, including new fees and licences, to conserve South Africa's scarce water resources.
Asmal said in a white paper on water policy, a discussion document which precedes the drafting of legislation, that a new system of allocating water would be introduced.

"The system will use water pricing, limited term allocations and other administrative mechanisms to bring supply and demand into balance in a manner which is beneficial in the public interest," the document said.
"The riparian system of allocation, in which the right to use water is tied to the ownership of the land along rivers, will effectively be abolished."
Asmal said the concept of ownership of water, like that pumped from boreholes, would be scrapped.

All water use would be subject to a catchment management charge and in some cases to a "resource conservation" charge. These charges would be waived if they hampered provision of water to the poor, Asmal said.
He said agriculture and mining would have to re-evaluate their consumption of water, saying crop irrigation accounted for about half the use of water in South Africa.
"They will have to pay a price for water that reflects the real economic cost, including the indirect costs to society and the environment for their water use," Asmal said.

"Under the new system, existing water users will have to apply for registration of their water use within a set time period. These applications will, where justified and possible, be converted into licences under the new law," he said.
